column4: I have a computer with Debian installed. Now is it possible for me to take a sources.list from Ubuntu and do an apt-get dist-upgrade and then get Ubuntu?
no
ok. Is there any way to do a thing like that? To "upgrade" from Debian to Ubuntu?
i do not think so :(.
Ok. Why not? I mean, what would go wrong if I tried it?
the packages are not the same on both distros you can end up with an unusable system. in warty it was possible iirci but not in breezy
hmm.... But would'nt it be possible to put warty sources in my sources.list, "upgrade" to Ubuntu warty, then put breezy sources in the sources.list and upgrade to Ubuntu breezy?
is a long and painfull way and as i said i'm not sure if it's possible. why not reinstall?
I do not have a CD-set.
download an iso and burn it
hmm... Yeah... I would like to do that... But my net is really slow.
if you make a net install you will be waiting forever too :(. i have 56 kbps modem too but persuade a friend of mine to dl the iso
ok.
but *does* Ubuntu have a net install image?
no afaik
ok.
Ok. I'm downloading the image now. What program should I use to burn it with? (I only have console)
cdrecord
ok.
install bum (graphical) or use update-rc.d (man update-rc.d)
I do not have GUI. Only CLI.
why did you compiled a external driver instead of using the provided one? /lib/modules/$(uname -r)/kernel/drivers/net/wireless/rt2x00/rt73usb.ko
I did not compile an external driver at first. It was because the provided one did not work.
you have to install the pae kernel
should I just install linux-generic-pae ?
yes
ok.
any drawbacks of using this kernel?
why isn't a PAE kernel image installed by the Ubuntu installer, if a PAE enabled CPU is detected?
there is a performance hit iirc. but i too use 64 bits so i can not tell if it matters in practice
if it is not needed is slower
ok. What are the drawbacks of using 64bit instead of 32bit? Other than problems getting Java working proberly?
how much slower? Where can I find info in this performance loss?
only the java plugin for mozilla is "somewhat" problematic
google should have plenty of hits
well, it is a show stopper me, because it makes me unable to use home banking.
a plugin is aviable based on openjdk that should be mostly compatible. you can try from a livecd
ok.
what package should I install to get it?
from a RH paper « The performance impact is highly workload dependent, but on a fairly typical kernel
so maximun 10% hit
ok.
most players can open iso files directly
i.e. « vlc file.iso » should just work
llutz: Ok. I was not aware. But I think using the terminal to start a video is too difficult for many users. Can this be done using GUI?
try it and see ?
I will. I am not on the system right now.
llutz: thanks for input.
7zip is your best option.
all compressions program in windows manage tar.gz and tar.bz2 without problems ...
ok. So how do I split it with tar?
but splitting in tar's is not easy either... use 7zip
how to use 7zip then?
install p7zip-full ; right click on the file you want to compress/split choose add to archive/compress
in the resulting dialog choose .7z as extension. click the plus to show options set volume size
I use Ark, but I cannot see where to set file size.
ok; commna line « 7z a -v4000m  file.7z file_to_compress »
that creates 4000 MiB volumes
thanks. And how to extract/join in Windows?
double click on the first volume ? ( if you have a half decent compression program ( 7-zip for windows is free and very good) all should work automatically
ok. Thanks.
or create a sfx archive?
sfx?
self extracting archives;
dunno if multivolume is compatible with sfx
oh.

I am using your proposed command right now, but it is very slow. The files that I am compressing cannot be compressed any futher, so I think that it is a waste to actually try to compress it. Does 7z have a 'fast' mode or something like that, that does not compress (much)?
thanks.
it depends on what you want to do
for some reason the Vista menu item no longer boots Vista. Instead it boots the wrong partition  --  The IBM rescue partition.
